docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 52 TAKING EVIDENCE FOR FOREIGN AND AUSTRALIAN COURTS AND TRIBUNALS [rr 52.1–52.6]

heading.title: PART 52 TAKING EVIDENCE FOR FOREIGN AND AUSTRALIAN COURTS AND TRIBUNALS [rr 52.1–52.6]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 52 TAKING EVIDENCE FOR FOREIGN AND AUSTRALIAN COURTS AND TRIBUNALS [rr 52.1–52.6]

leg:heading.title: TAKING EVIDENCE FOR FOREIGN AND AUSTRALIAN COURTS AND TRIBUNALS [rr 52.1–52.6]

p.text: [Pt 52 insrt Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 5 October 2007]

entry.emph: Taking evidence for foreign and Australian courts and tribunals — Rules 52.1–52.6

row.entry: This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court for orders under ss 32 and 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995, for the compulsory examination of witnesses in connection with proceedings in foreign tribunals. The procedures under UCPR Pt 24 , with the modifications expressed in this Part, apply to the conduct of the examination: see the annotations to UCPR Pt 24 for the detailed procedures and commentary.
Applications for orders under ss 32 and 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act may only be made in the Supreme Court. The rules in this part apply to those proceedings.
The rules substantially replicate the former SCR Pt 58 with some minor modifications.
Application of other rules to taking of evidence ‥ r 52.2
Examination pursuant to letters of request ‥ [52.1.5]
Transcript of evidence and exhibits ‥ r 52.4

p.text: Proceedings for an order under section 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 in relation to a matter pending before a requesting court may be commenced in the Supreme Court:
by a person nominated for that purpose by the requesting court, or
if no person is so nominated, by the Attorney General.
In proceedings for such an order, no person is required to be joined as a defendant.

If proceedings for such an order have been commenced in relation to a matter pending before a requesting court, any other application for such an order in relation to the same matter is to be made by notice of motion in the proceedings.
Rules 52.2–52.5 have effect unless the Supreme Court otherwise orders.

level.toc-caption: [52.1.5] Examination pursuant to letters of request

p.text: Legislation cited in [52.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 33(6), s 80(1)(a).

heading.title: Examination pursuant to letters of request

p.text: Comity requires that a request made by a foreign court, for the purpose of proceedings within its jurisdiction, for evidence to be taken within the local forum, should be dealt with sympathetically and complied with so far as local law permits: Seyfang v GD Searle & Co [1973] QB 148 at 151–2; [1973] 1 All ER 290 ; Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547 at 560, 612, 654; [1978] 1 All ER 434; [1978] 2 WLR 81 ; Re Asbestos Insurance Coverage Cases [1985] 1 All ER 716; [1985] 1 WLR 331 at 335, 339–40 . Consequently, although the Local Court must be affirmatively satisfied that a request has been made for a proper purpose (see s 32(1) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995), that satisfaction may be substantially derived from the fact and content of the foreign court's request; Re Application of Forsyth; Cordova v Phillips Roxanne Laboratories Inc [1984] 2 NSWLR 327 at 333–4 ; Pickles v Gratzon (2002) 55 NSWLR 533; [2002] NSWSC 688; BC200204345 (not following National Mutual Holdings Pty Ltd v Sentry Corp (FCA, 30 May 1990, unreported)); and does not require satisfaction that the permissible purpose is either "sole" or "dominant": Re Application of Forsyth; Cordova v Phillips Roxanne Laboratories Inc, above, at 333–4. The degree of particularity contained in a request is capable of influencing, but is not in itself a precondition of, the exercise of the discretion to make an order under s 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995: Pickles v Gratzon (2002) 55 NSWLR 533 at 551–2; [2002] NSWSC 688; BC200204345 ; Lenning v Alexander Proudfoot Co World Headquarters (NSWCA, 22 April 1991, unreported, BC9102086)(order under s 80(1)(a) of the Evidence Act 1898 limiting the questions which might be asked). On the other hand, s 33(6) of the Act precludes orders being made that would impose a "discovery" obligation in relation to the identification and production of documents: Radio Corp of America v Rauland Corp [1956] 1 QB 618 at 648, 649; [1956] 1 All ER 549; [1956] 2 WLR 612 ; Pickles v Gratzon, above, at 553; Re Westinghouse Electric Corp Uranium Contract Litigation MDL Docket No 235 (No 2) [1978] AC 547; [1977] 3 All ER 717; [1978] 2 WLR 81 ; Re Norway's Application [1987] 1 QB 433. Similarly, a witness should not be required to submit to an examination for the purposes of a foreign tribunal unless they would be compellable to give evidence in connection with proceedings conducted in the local forum: Re S [1948] VLR 11; [1948] 1 ALR 81 ; Seyfang v GD Searle & Co, above, at 152.
Legislation cited in [52.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Sch 8.

Proceedings for an order under s 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 in relation to a matter pending before a requesting court will be assigned to the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court: see UCPR Sch 8 .
Legislation cited in [52.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.1A.
See UCPR r 6.1A .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 52.2] r 52.2 Application of other rules regarding the taking of evidence (cf SCR Part 58, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Application of other rules regarding the taking of evidence (cf SCR Part 58, rule 2)

p.text: Subject to this Part, rules 24.7–24.16 apply to an examination held pursuant to an order under this Part:
as if the matter pending before the requesting court were proceedings in the Supreme Court, and
as if the order had been made under rule 24.3 in proceedings in the Supreme Court, and

if a Judge, associate Judge or registrar is appointed under section 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995, as if an order had been made under rule 24.3 for the examination of a person on oath before a Judge, associate Judge or registrar.

Section 33(1) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 gives the court a wide discretion to make appropriate provision (including restrictive directions and orders for legal representation) for giving effect to the request of the foreign tribunal: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547; [1978] 1 All ER 434; [1978] 2 WLR 81; AC at 611 per Lord Wilberforce; AC at 562–3 per Lord Denning MR; Re Norway's Application [1987] 1 QB 433 at 466, 484, 491; Re Norway's Application (No 2) [1990] 1 AC 723 at 782 per Woolf LJ; [1989] 1 All ER 745 ; Lenning v Alexander Proudfoot Co World Headquarters (NSWCA, Kirby P, Priestley and Clarke JJA, 22 April 1991, unreported, BC9102086). The discretion is subject to limitations that the order can only require conduct that could be compelled for the taking of evidence in proceedings in the court: see s 33(4) and (6) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995. The limitations have an uncertain operation where restrictions on the compellability of a witness are related to the admissibility of the proposed evidence. Often the examiner may be entitled to assume (in the absence of contrary evidence) that admissibility is the same in both jurisdictions: Re Norway's Application, above, at 492; Harris v Barker (1986) 42 SASR 316 . This assumption is notoriously invalid in relation to the admissibility of “discovery” type questions in US civil proceedings. In that context, the statutory limitations have been regarded as prohibiting questions designed to obtain discovery of documents and as confining the scope of any examination to the kinds of material that would be permissible in proceedings in the court: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp, above, AC at 562 per Lord Denning MR; AC at 608–9 per Lord Wilberforce; First American Corp v Sheikh Zayed Al-Nahyan [1998] 4 All ER 439; [1999] 1 WLR 1154 ; Genira Trade & Finance Inc v Recto Capital Markets Ltd [2001] EWCA Civ 1733 ; Golden Eagle Refinery Co Ltd v Associated International Insurance Co [1998] EWCA Civ 293 at 5 and 10; Minnesota v Phillip Morris Inc [1997] EWCA Civ 2241 at 7 and 13. Applying the statutory limitations (and any complementary directions of the court) may be particularly difficult in such cases. There are two reasons for that difficulty. The first is the absence of a clear line of differentiation between evidence that is “directly” probative of a fact in issue, and evidence that is only “indirectly” relevant. The second is that the examiner cannot formally determine the admissibility of evidence in the foreign proceedings — that admissibility being a matter for the foreign court itself. This requires an examiner to apply the statutory limitations with a proper regard to the ultimate authority of the requesting court to determine ordinary relevance issues in the proceedings: Re Norway's Application, above, at 492 per Roskill LJ. Subject to the procedural difficulties that may arise from the disputed admissibility of questions, UCPR r 24.9 also contemplates that, subject to any contrary order, the examination procedure should be the same as that governing the course of evidence at a trial; British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Eubanks (2004) 60 NSWLR 483; [2004] NSWCA 158; BC200402800 .

The procedures and powers authorised by ss 32 and 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 are limited to orders for obtaining evidence in response to a letter of request from a foreign tribunal. Although s 33(3)(b) of the Act expressly confers an ancillary power to require the production of documents, its scope is itself limited by both the general purpose of the power (see [24.5.20] ) and the prohibition on “discovery” contained in s 33(6) of the Act. That subsection reflects Australia’s declaration, pursuant to Article 23 of the Hague Convention on the Taking of Evidence Abroad in Civil or Commercial Matters, refusing the enforcement of letters of request seeking discovery (see [24.5.10] ) and Re Asbestos Insurance Coverage Cases [1985] 1 All ER 716; [1985] 1 WLR 331 at 336 ; British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Eubanks (2004) 60 NSWLR 483; [2004] NSWCA 158; BC200402800 . Consistent with that reservation, s 33(6) of the Act limits orders for production to “particular documents specified” and “likely” to be in the person’s control. This restriction has been said to require strict interpretation: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547; [1978] 1 All ER 434; [1978] 2 WLR 81 AC at 609 per Lord Wilberforce. Nevertheless, it has provoked differing views about the sufficiency of the descriptions of “particular” documents in orders for production under the Act. The general prohibition on “discovery”, in the sense explained in [33.4.20]–[33.4.25] , is uncontroversial. However, various authorities contemplate that the limitation to “particular” documents implies further restrictions which (i) preclude the requirement to produce classes or categories of documents: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp, above, AC at 610 per Lord Wilberforce; AC at 625 per Viscount Dilhorne; AC at 635 per Lord Diplock; AC at 644 per Lord Fraser; AC at 654 per Lord Keith; and, (ii) only require the production of documents whose existence is probable, not merely conjectured as possible: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp, above, AC at 609 per Lord Wilberforce; AC at 644 per Lord Fraser; Re Asbestos Insurance Coverage Cases [1985] 1 All ER 716; [1985] 1 WLR 331 at 338 . Within these contemplated limitations the possible sufficiency of orders requiring the production of documents “referring” or “relating” to specified subject matters, remains a matter requiring impressionistic judgment in the particular circumstances: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp, above, AC at 563 per Lord Denning MR; AC at 570 per Lord Roskill; AC at 611 per Lord Wilberforce; AC at 625 per Viscount Dilhorne; AC at 635 per Lord Diplock; AC at 644 per Lord Fraser; AC at 654 per Lord Keith.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 52.3] r 52.3 Attendance of applicant (cf SCR Part 58, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Attendance of applicant (cf SCR Part 58, rule 3)

p.text: The person commencing proceedings under this Part may attend and take part in the examination.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 52.4] r 52.4 Transcript of evidence and exhibits (cf SCR Part 58, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Transcript of evidence and exhibits (cf SCR Part 58, rule 4)

p.text: The provisions of rule 24.14(4) and (5) do not apply to an examination under this Part.

Subject to rule 52.6, the examiner must send the transcript of evidence and any document which constitutes a recording under rule 24.13 (which relates to videotape, etc) to the principal registrar of the Supreme Court.

An examiner who receives an exhibit on production by any person must, at the conclusion of the examination, return the exhibit to the person producing it unless that person consents to the retention of the exhibit.
If the examiner retains the exhibit, he or she must send it to the principal registrar of the Supreme Court together with the transcript of evidence.
On receipt of a transcript of evidence taken under this Part, a registrar of the Supreme Court:
must issue a certificate, sealed with the seal of the Supreme Court, annexing and identifying:
the request, and
the order of the Court for examination, and
the transcript of evidence, and
any document that constitutes a recording under rule 24.13, and
any exhibits received from the examiner, and
must send the certificate and annexures to the Attorney General or, if the request was sent to the Supreme Court by some other person pursuant to a convention, to that other person.
[r 52.5 am Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[12], [13], effective 6 March 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 52.6] r 52.6 Privilege of witness (cf SCR Part 58, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Privilege of witness (cf SCR Part 58, rule 6)

p.text: This rule applies if a claim by a witness to be exempt from giving any evidence on the ground specified in section 34(1)(b) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995 is not supported or conceded as mentioned in section 34(2) of that Act.
The witness may be required to give the evidence to which the claim relates:
by the examiner, or
if the examiner does not so require, by the Supreme Court on the application of the person who obtained the order under section 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995.
An application referred to in subrule (2)(b) need not be served on any person unless the Supreme Court otherwise orders.
The following provisions apply if the evidence is taken pursuant to such a requirement:
the evidence must be recorded in a transcript (the disputed transcript) that is separate to the transcript in which the rest of the witness’s evidence is recorded,

the transcript of evidence that is sent to the principal registrar of the Supreme Court must be accompanied by a statement, signed by the examiner, setting out the claim and the ground on which it was made,
on receipt of the statement, the principal registrar of the Supreme Court:
must retain the disputed transcript, and
must send to the requesting court, together with the documents mentioned in rule 52.4, both the statement and a request to determine the claim,
on receiving notice of the requesting court's determination of the claim, the principal registrar of the Supreme Court:
if the claim is rejected, must send the disputed transcript to the requesting court, or
if the claim is upheld, must send the disputed transcript to the witness,
and, in either case, must cause notice of the determination to be given both to the witness and to the person who obtained the order under section 33 of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995.
